H0.text: The apple trees could not make leaves if pesticides killed all the pollinators near them.

H1.text: The trees could not make flowers if pesticides killed all the pollinators near some apple trees.

H2.text: The trees could not make seeds if pesticides kill all the pollinators near some apple trees.

H3.text: The trees could not make bark if pesticides killed all the pollinators near some apple trees.

A4.text: More than 87.5% of angiosperms, over 75% of tropical tree species, and 30â€“40% of tree species in temperate regions depend on pollination and seed dispersal.

A5.text: The vicinity of a forest or wild grasslands with native pollinators near agricultural crops, such as apples, almonds or coffee can improve their yield by about 20%.

A6.text: Honey bees and orchard mason bees are used by apple growers to carry pollen during flowering.

A7.text: Cultivars are sometimes classified by the day of peak bloom in the average 30-day blossom period, with pollinizers selected from cultivars within a 6-day overlap period.

A8.text: Bees care for their brood, they need to collect more food than just to maintain themselves, and therefore are important pollinators.

A9.text: A decline, for whatever reason, to one side of this partnership can be catastrophic for the other.

A10.text: The transfer of pollen (the male gametophytes) to the female stigmas occurs is called pollination. After pollination occurs, the pollen grain germinates to form a pollen tube that grows through the carpel's style and transports male nuclei to the ovule to fertilize the egg cell and central cell within the female gametophyte in a process termed double fertilization.

A11.text: Apples, blueberries, and cherries are 90% dependent on honeybee pollination.

A12.text: No crops originating in the New World depend on the western honey bee, as the bee is an invasive species.
